      • getConversionSequence

        private static java.util.List<Term> getConversionSequence(Term initial,
                                                          Term goal,
                                                          Term convergence,
                                                          java.util.Map<Term,Term> leftSteps,
                                                          java.util.Map<Term,Term> rightSteps)
        Returns a list of terms that represents the conversion steps that were used in the conversion from the term initial to the term goal. This conversion is found using a Breadth-First Search starting from both initial and goal and a set of equations, which therefore creates two sets of terms, terms that can be found by rewriting initial and terms that can be found by rewriting goal. The map leftSteps stores for each term which term was used to create it, for all terms found by rewriting initial. This allows us to trace back the steps that were used for the conversion. rightSteps does the same for terms created by rewriting goal. When a term is found that is common to both sets of terms, there exists a conversion from initial to goal. There can be multiple common terms, convergence is one of those common terms.
        Parameters:
        initial - The initial term where the conversion starts
        goal - The final term where the conversion ends
        convergence - A term that both initial and goal can be rewritten to
        leftSteps - A map that links each term to the term that was used to create it, from convergence to initial
        rightSteps - A map that links each term to the term that was used to create it, from convergence to goal
        Returns:
        A list of terms which represents the conversion steps that were used to rewrite initial to goal
        See Also:
        Term

      • checkConvergence

        private static Term checkConvergence(java.util.Set<Term> left,
                                     java.util.Set<Term> right)
        Checks convergence between two terms by checking whether the set of terms created from a term has a term in common by the set of terms created from a second term
        Parameters:
        left - The first set of terms
        right - The second set of terms
        Returns:
        A term that is common between left and right, or null if no such term exists

      • generateTerms

        private static java.util.Set<Term> generateTerms(java.util.Set<Term> terms,
                                                 Term term,
                                                 java.util.Map<Variable,Term> subs,
                                                 int maxTermDepth)
        Generates all possible terms that can be obtained by substituting the variables in term by the terms in terms.
        Parameters:
        terms - A set of terms
        term - A term with 0 or more variables
        subs - A map that contains the current substitutions
        maxTermDepth - The maximum depth a term is allowed, terms with higher depth will not be in the set that is returned
        Returns:
        A set of terms that can be created by substituting free variables (i.e. those not occuring in subs) in term by terms in the set terms
        See Also:
        Term, Variable

      • getTerms

        private static java.util.List<Term> getTerms(EquationSystem system,
                                             int maxTermDepth,
                                             int k)
        Generates a set of (small) terms that can be used to generate lemmas. This is done by creating the term f(x1, ..., xn) for every f : s1, ..., sn to s in Sigma in system the variables x_i are fresh variables of sort s_i for i = 1, ..., n The term and its variables are added to a set and combined k times by substituting variables by different terms of the same sort.
        Parameters:
        system - A system of equations over a set of operators sigma, a subset of constructors C, and a goal equation that should be proven
        maxTermDepth - The maximum depth a term is allowed to have
        k - The amount of times terms are combined to generate new terms
        Returns:
        A set of (small) terms of all functions in system.Sigma
        See Also:
        EquationSystem
